Description: The maximum value of the observation over the output interval
The minimum value of the observation over the output interval
The value of the observation at the measurement time
An upside down bucket-shaped collection device is placed on the ground surface. A sensor in the chamber measures the concentration of gas coming from the ground beneath the chamber
While an aircraft flies through a plume at different altitudes, a pump inside the aircraft sucks in gases and instruments measure the concentration
A correlation spectrometer that measures absorption of ultraviolet light by SO2 from beneath a volcanic plume
A miniaturised UV spectrometer system that measures absorption of ultraviolet light by SO2 from beneath a volcanic plume
Using a photographic image and a natural  object of known or estimated size in the image, estimate the size of another object or the distance between two points in the image
A thermometer which infers temperature from a portion of the thermal radiation spectrum. Sometimes called a laser thermometer or temperature gun

A lake is used like a large tiltmeter. Water level is measured “”simultaneously”" at multiple points around the lake shore relative to a reference point. The water level can be used as a proxy for ground uplift or subsidence
Use of an optical level and survey staff to measure the relative height between two locations, and subsequently round a network of points, returning to the starting location
A count of the total number of events in a given time period. The count of either carried out completely manually, or has a manual review of an automatic detection process
A differential optical absorption spectrometry (DOAS) instrument that is small enough to be operated from an aircraft and make observations of SO2 concentration from beneath a volcanic plume
Photographing a water surface against a staff gauge and using that to estimate the water level to a precision greater than that of markings on the staff gauge
A calibrated scale which used to provide a visual indication of water level
A thermographic camera that senses infrared radiation
A thermoelectrical thermometer
A mercury thermometer
A measurement of vertical angle and distance using a laser rangefinder
A physical sample is analysed in a laboratory. For water samples, this is typically the New Zealand Geothermal Analytical Laboratory (NZGAL)
